Boualem Sansal, French-Algerian writer detained in Algeria, receives pardon
subhead: Sansal's incarceration since November 2024 had been at the heart of a diplomatic row between France and Algeria. Following mediation by Germany, Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune issued a pardon.

title: Amid Shein controversy, Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com sets sights on European market
subhead: France's government is closely monitoring the Chinese company's takeover offer for German firm Ceconomy, the second-largest shareholder of the Fnac Darty retail group. In France, JD.com has been hiring on a large scale to discreetly develop a new online retail service to rival Amazon.

title: Antonin Tron appointed Balmain's new creative director
subhead: The 41-year-old French designer, who founded his own label Atlein and worked for several prestigious Parisian fashion houses, has been chosen to succeed Olivier Rousteing.

title: 10 years after Paris attacks: Researchers studying survivors' memories 'owe it to victims'
subhead: In a joint interview, Denis Peschanski and Francis Eustache discuss the November 13 Program, launched in early 2016. This unique multidisciplinary project combines research in the humanities, social sciences and neuroscience.

The new malaise of civilization: When words, truth and reality fall apart
subhead: The proliferation of wars, increase in mental health disorders, devaluation of speech, and loss of connection to reality are troubling signs of the tipping point our societies are facing. Nearly a century ago, Freud identified a malaise that resonates with what we are going through today.

title: Among France's centrists, Macron's succession is still anyone's game
subhead: A year and a half ahead of the 2027 presidential election, no 'natural' candidate has managed to dominate the fractured former majority coalition. Edouard Philippe, the only declared candidate, has distanced himself from Emmanuel Macron, while Gabriel Attal has held back.

title: Nicolas Sarkozy leaves jail under strict judicial supervision
subhead: The former president cannot leave France and is prohibited from contacting any of the 17 individuals associated with the investigation. The court also barred him from meeting with any senior official with access to confidential information.
